title: 103_s1683
content: The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 allows for land acquisition. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance it. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to manage the land acquired from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region to enhance protection of watershed, outdoor recreation, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized for the SEC. 3 Authorization of Appropriations. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to appropriate $35,000,000 for acquiring land described in section 2. Funds made available shall be transferred to the Commission as necessary to carry out this Act. The Act is titled the "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994". The Palisades Interstate Park Commission manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. It receives over 8 million visitors annually for outdoor recreational activities. Sterling Forest in New Jersey is a biologically diverse open space spanning 17,500 acres and serving as a significant watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. Sterling Forest is a biologically diverse open space on the New Jersey border, comprising 17,500 acres. It is a significant watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. Additionally, it is an important outdoor recreational asset in the densely populated northeastern United States, supporting a mixture of hardwood forests, wetlands, lakes, and providing important habitat for wildlife. Sterling Forest in the northeastern United States supports a mixture of hardwood forests, wetlands, lakes, and provides habitat for rare species. Protecting Sterling Forest would enhance the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and provide recreational opportunities. The protection of Sterling Forest would greatly enhance the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and provide recreational opportunities. Stewardship costs for the Palisades Park System are covered by New York and New Jersey, minimizing the need for federal funds. The protection of Sterling Forest through the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will involve minimal Federal funds due to stewardship costs being covered by New York and New Jersey. The nationally significant watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities of Sterling Forest, along with the demand for open space in the northeastern United States, highlight a clear Federal interest in acquiring the area. The nationally significant qualities of Sterling Forest, including its watershed, recreational, and wildlife aspects, along with the demand for open space in the northeastern United States, emphasize the clear Federal interest in acquiring the area for permanent protection. This investment is cost-effective compared to the expenses that would be needed to protect the region's drinking water if Sterling Forest were to be developed. The purpose of acquiring Sterling Forest for permanent protection is to preserve its nationally significant qualities, including its watershed, recreational, and wildlife aspects, in response to the demand for open space in the northeastern United States. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources in the region. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will convey certain interests in lands to the Secretary of the Interior for management of the Reserve. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established to protect watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources. Federal funding is authorized for acquisition costs, and the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will convey certain interests in lands to the Secretary of the Interior for management of the Reserve. The Act defines key terms such as "Commission" as the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, "Reserve" as the Sterling Forest Reserve, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The Act also establishes the Sterling Forest Reserve. The Sterling Forest Reserve in New York is established by the Commission upon acquiring sufficient lands. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres as depicted on a map available for public inspection. The Commission acquired approximately 17,500 acres of lands for the Sterling Forest Reserve, as shown on the Boundary Map SFR-60,001 dated July 1, 1994. The map is available for public inspection. The Secretary will transfer funds for land acquisition within the Reserve, subject to specified conditions. The Secretary will transfer funds to the Commission for land acquisition within the Reserve, subject to specified conditions. If the Commission fails to manage the acquired lands in accordance with the Act, they must convey fee title to the United States. Prior to receiving Federal funds, the Commission must agree to convey fee title to the United States if they fail to manage acquired lands as per the Act. Lands can only be acquired with Federal funds with the owner's consent. The Commission must convey fee title to the United States for lands acquired with Federal funds, with the owner's consent. If unable to acquire all lands within the Reserve, the Commission shall acquire National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands. The Commission must acquire National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands within the Reserve if unable to acquire all lands with Federal funds and owner consent. The Commission must convey conservation easements on National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands within 30 days of acquisition. The Commission shall convey conservation easements on National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands to protect their wilderness character. The easement lands described on the map in section 5(b) will be managed to protect their wilderness character. Conservation easements on National Park Service Conservation Easement Lands will restrict development and use to be compatible with the protection of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. The easement lands on the map in section 5(b) will restrict development to protect the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. Funds for the Commission must be matched by non-Federal sources. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT OF THE RESERVE. The Commission will manage acquired lands in line with its authorities and the Act's purposes. Within 3 years, a general management plan must be prepared and submitted for approval by the Secretary. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to be appropriated for this Act, with a limit of $17,500,000 for land acquisition within the Reserve.
